moves.6... e5 7. O-O exd4: King's Indian exchange, which isn't common to most players. White or Black should know how to play this line. Take me for example, I lost a point in a OTB chess tournament once, and I've only played against it once in a tournament, because I was dumbfounded when an opponent decided to play this line; I was not ready and didn't even know what the lines were!
moves.8. Nxd4 a6 9. Be3 Nbd7 10. f3: At this point I didn't know what he had in mind. I knew f3 was common in this line so I followed suite.
moves.10... Nb6 11. Nc2: Again, a common move to play in this line and I wanted to preserve the Knight.
moves.11... c5 12. Qd2 Be6 13. b3 Qc7 14. g4 N: I wanted to traded bishops. Pawn-g5 would block my bishop and the diagonal.
moves.17... Rab8 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4: OH! Also, I wanted to play this move and w/o the Knight on e3, I wouldn't have been able to do so. Hence, the knight move on move 17.
moves.19... Nc6 20. Bxh5 gxh5 21. f5 Bd7 22. f: I thought this to be the best continuation as he's unable to move the Pawn-f7, forced to the back eighth row, and rooks remain out of play.  King-g6 seem suicidal
moves.25. Qxg5 Rg8 26. Qxg8+ Kxg8 27. Ncd5: Time to defend. This move blocks the Pawn-d, while attacking.

gameName: Check out this to be checkmate
